fr:mainmatter.html:p: A stable class of families of sets is definable when any family of sets can be restricted to a “biggest” subfamily that lies in the class.
To motivate Bénabou’s general notion of definability, we will first develop an alternative perspective on definability for classes of sets in terms of families of sets.

fr:title.text: Closure of a class of sets under base change

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of a class of sets under base change

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathfrak {C}\subseteq \mathscr {M} be a class of sets; there exists a class \bar {\mathfrak {C}} of families of sets that contains {\mathopen {}\left (S_{i}\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} exactly when each S_{i} lies in \mathfrak {C}. We will refer to \bar {\mathfrak {C}} as the closure under base change of \mathfrak {C}, a name motivated by the fact that when {\mathopen {}\left (S_{i}\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} lies in \bar {\mathfrak {C}}, then for any u:J\to I, the base change {\mathopen {}\left (S_{uj}\right )\mathclose {}}_{j\in J} also lies in \bar {\mathfrak {C}}.

fr:title.text: From classes of families to classes of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From classes of families to classes of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Conversely to the closure of a class of sets under change of base, we may take a class of families of sets \mathfrak {F} to the the class of sets \mathfrak {F}_{1}\subseteq {\mathscr {M}} spanned by sets S such that the singleton family {\mathopen {}\left \{S\right \}\mathclose {}} lies in \mathfrak {C}.

fr:title.text: Definable class of families of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Definable class of families of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A class of families of sets \mathfrak {F} is said to be definable when it is stable and moreover, for any family of sets {\mathopen {}\left (S_{i}\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I}, there exists a subset J\subseteq I such that the base change {\mathopen {}\left (S_{j}\right )\mathclose {}}_{j\in J} lies in \mathfrak {F}, and moreover, such that u:K\to I factors through J\subseteq I whenever the base change {\mathopen {}\left (S_{uk}\right )\mathclose {}}_{k\in K} lies in \mathfrak {F}.
A stable class of families of sets is definable when any family of sets can be restricted to a “biggest” subfamily that lies in the class.

fr:title.text: Characterization of definable classes of families

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterization of definable classes of families

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathfrak {C}\subseteq \mathscr {M} be a class of sets; then \bar {\mathfrak {C}} is a definable class of families of sets if and only if \mathfrak {C} is a definable class of sets.

Suppose that \mathfrak {C} is a definable class of sets. To check that \bar {\mathfrak {C}} is a definable class of families of sets, we fix a family {\mathopen {}\left (S_{i}\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} not necessarily lying in \bar {\mathfrak {C}}. Because \mathfrak {C} is definable, the intersection \mathfrak {C}\cap \bigcup _{i\in I}S_{i} is represented by a set U. We therefore take the subset J = {\mathopen {}\left \{i \in I\mid S_i\in U\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq I, and verify that the base change {\mathopen {}\left (S_{j}\right )\mathclose {}}_{j\in J} is the largest approximation of {\mathopen {}\left (S_{i}\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} by a family lying in \bar {\mathfrak {C}}.

Conversely suppose that \bar {\mathfrak {C}} is a definable class of families of sets. To see that \mathfrak {C} is definable, we fix a class \mathfrak {U} represented by a set U\in \mathscr {M} to check that \mathfrak {C}\cap \mathfrak {U} is representable. We consider the family of sets {\mathopen {}\left (u\right )\mathclose {}}_{u\in U}; because \bar {\mathfrak {C}} is definable, there is a largest subset V\subseteq U such that the change of base {\mathopen {}\left (v\right )\mathclose {}}_{v\in V} lies in \bar {\mathfrak {C}}, i.e. such that each v\in V lies in \mathfrak {C}. Therefore \mathfrak {C}\cap \mathfrak {U} is represented by the set V.
